comment._content: Wow. How could Mrs Tickle have kept a steady hand writing this? Heart-breaking and humbling. But proud and grateful!

comment._content: what a handsome man

comment.author: 69684841@N02
comment._content: He is the spitting image of Steve Gerrard who plays for liverpool !

comment.author: 16002177@N05
comment._content:
John you are the idiot! These were just children who many went off as their only chance of seeing the World & for many escaping grinding poverty.
My Grandfather was very badly wounded during WW1-he felt he was serving King,Country & protecting his family-dirty words nowadays.
My Mother's Uncle was only 16 when he received the wounds which would kill him three years later-after three years of paralysis.
You might call them idiots I think of them as brave but foolish boys who thought they were doing their duty.

comment.author: 69670586@N05
comment._content: gill he was calling wobblybob an idiot actually

comment.author: 10492315@N03
comment._content: Pity about the stupid comments

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: We appreciate all genuine comments and we know you have strong passions about the First World War, but we would like the tone to be kept civil. If you have a spare minute, please light a light to help us remember those who died in the First World War, at www.1914.org/wall/

comment.author: 10492315@N03
comment._content:
Good to see that the comments are subject to moderation, may I suggest that the offensive comments be deleted and the individuals blocked from making any further crass remarks. I understand that this excellent IWM group is intended for those who have further info on the subjects to be able to add such info, not as some general discussion of the conflict or of the individuals portrayed.

Norman

comment.author: 69716811@N07
comment._content: What a lovely looking boy - because that's all he was at the time - but doing a man's job - so brave - all of them - this site is amazing - thank you IWM for bringing it to us - I have done the light a light.

comment.author: 69699566@N03
comment._content:
Parents Marriage
On 17th July 1880 at St John Bethnal Green London Eliza Annie Schultz 21yrs spinster married Digby Conynghane Tickle 21yrs bachelor Clerk both of St Johns Parish
Fathers Joseph Tickle Solicitor & Henry Schultz deceased Accountant
Witnesses Nathan Charles Clark & Louise Charlotte Hainbridge

Marriage Registered at Bethnal Green Sep 1880 Vol. 1c Page 477

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
The 1901 Family home at 169 Neville Road still exists [and I cannot find any trace that it has been re-numbered]. It was narrowly missed [by 100 yards] on the 28th January 1945 by a V2 rocket.
Below is a picture of the house. Click for a bigger version.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6359278659/in/photostream]

comment.author: 70210658@N08
comment._content:
British Army Medal Rolls

Victory Medal Roll K/2/102B5 Page 204
British Medal Roll K/2/102B5 Page 204
Star Medal Roll K/2/12B Page 56

Served in Western Theatre from 14th August 1915
Killed in Action 3/7/16

Notes on Medal Card: Mrs E A Tickle applies for 1914-15 Star in respect of the services of her late son 27 3 19.
Reply on  25 4 19 (Medal added)

Address 6 Dickinson Road Crouch Hill N8

comment.author: 72079890@N08
comment._content: I think that Billy should be the 'Face' of WW1.......Young, brave wanting to do right for his country and loved by his Mum........Just like the millions that died with him.

comment.author: 65287373@N07
comment._content: I stumbled across this photo accidently, and was completely shocked when I saw it because this boy is the image of my brother.  When I clicked on the picture and saw that he has the same second name as me, I actually couldn’t believe it. Furthermore, my father and uncle think that their grandfather had a brother named William, and that their mother was called Elizabeth. I would really love to find out anything that I can about William, and would appreciate any help. Thanks, Laura.

comment.author: 92547651@N03
comment._content: I'm a William C Tickle in southern Louisiana...this site is honorable and amazing for remembering those that fought to protect the freedom of the world. -w.c. tickle

comment.author: 61207511@N03
comment._content: Very poignant and moving. Great that this young lad and his bright smile live on in the digital age . .
